problems.subject: Physics
problems.problemStatement: A displacement vector of magnitude 10 m is at 30° above the horizontal. Find the horizontal and vertical components of this displacement.

steps.stepDescription: Determine what information we have from the problem
steps.correctAnswer: Magnitude A = 10 m, angle θ = 30° above horizontal
options: Magnitude A = 10 m, angle θ = 30° above horizontal
Magnitude A = 30 m, angle θ = 10° above horizontal
Magnitude A = 10 m, angle θ = 60° above horizontal
Magnitude A = 10 m, angle θ = 30° below horizontal
steps.explanation: The problem clearly states magnitude is 10 m and angle is 30° above the horizontal. Reading the problem carefully prevents common mistakes.

steps.stepDescription: Use horizontal and vertical component equations
steps.correctAnswer: Ax = A cos(θ) = 10 cos(30°), Ay = A sin(θ) = 10 sin(30°)
options: Ax = A cos(θ) = 10 cos(30°), Ay = A sin(θ) = 10 sin(30°)
Ax = A sin(θ) = 10 sin(30°), Ay = A cos(θ) = 10 cos(30°)
Ax = A tan(θ) = 10 tan(30°), Ay = A cos(θ) = 10 cos(30°)
Ax = A cos(θ) = 10 cos(60°), Ay = A sin(θ) = 10 sin(60°)
steps.explanation: For an angle measured from horizontal: use cos for horizontal (adjacent) and sin for vertical (opposite). Confusing sin/cos is a common error.

steps.stepDescription: Substitute trigonometric values
steps.explanation: cos(30°) ≈ 0.866, sin(30°) = 0.5. Students often swap these values or use wrong angle values.

keyLearningObjectives: Distinguish between horizontal and vertical components
commonMisconceptions: Confusing sin and cos when decomposing vectors
Using the complement angle instead of the given angle
Not recognizing that components must be smaller than the vector magnitude

problems.subject: Physics
problems.problemStatement: A projectile is launched at 25 m/s at an angle of 37° above the horizontal from ground level. Calculate the horizontal range. (Take g = 10 m/s², sin(37°) = 0.6, cos(37°) = 0.8, sin(74°) = 0.96)

steps.stepDescription: Decompose initial velocity into horizontal and vertical components
options: V₀ₓ = 25 m/s, V₀ᵧ = 0 m/s
steps.explanation: Horizontal component uses cos (angle from horizontal), vertical uses sin. Option 2 is a classic sin/cos swap error.

steps.stepDescription: Find how long the projectile stays in air using vertical motion
steps.correctAnswer: T = 2V₀ᵧ/g = 2 × 15/10 = 3 seconds
options: T = 2V₀ᵧ/g = 2 × 15/10 = 3 seconds
T = V₀ᵧ/g = 15/10 = 1.5 seconds
T = V₀ᵧ²/(2g) = 225/20 = 11.25 seconds
T = 2V₀ₓ/g = 2 × 20/10 = 4 seconds
steps.explanation: Time of flight depends only on vertical motion. The formula T = 2V₀ᵧ/g is for launch and landing at same height. Using horizontal velocity is incorrect.

steps.stepDescription: Range = horizontal velocity × time of flight
steps.explanation: Only horizontal velocity contributes to horizontal distance. Vertical velocity affects flight time, not range directly. This requires understanding decoupling of motion.

keyLearningObjectives: Understand independence of horizontal and vertical motion
Apply kinematic equations to projectile motion
commonMisconceptions: Thinking vertical velocity affects horizontal distance
Using sin and cos incorrectly for angle decomposition
Not recognizing that horizontal velocity remains constant

problems.subject: Physics
problems.problemStatement: A block of mass 5 kg is placed on a smooth inclined plane inclined at 37° to the horizontal. The block is connected by a string over a pulley to a hanging mass of 3 kg. Find the acceleration of the system. (g = 10 m/s², sin(37°) = 0.6, cos(37°) = 0.8)

steps.stepTitle: Draw free body diagrams and identify forces
steps.stepDescription: Analyze forces on both masses separately
steps.correctAnswer: Block on plane: Component down plane = m₁g sin(37°) = 50 × 0.6 = 30 N (no friction), Tension T acts up plane. Hanging mass: Weight = m₂g = 30 N down, Tension T acts up.
options: Block on plane: Component down plane = m₁g sin(37°) = 50 × 0.6 = 30 N (no friction), Tension T acts up plane. Hanging mass: Weight = m₂g = 30 N down, Tension T acts up.
Block on plane: Component down plane = m₁g cos(37°) = 50 × 0.8 = 40 N, Normal force = 30 N. Hanging mass: Weight = 30 N.
Block on plane experiences friction. Hanging mass has no weight.
Both masses have identical forces and must move with same velocity.
steps.explanation: For motion down the plane, sin(θ) gives component along plane. cos(θ) gives normal force. 'Smooth' means frictionless. The hanging mass creates tension pulling the block up the plane.

steps.stepTitle: Write equations of motion for both masses
steps.stepDescription: Apply Newton's second law (F_net = ma) to each mass with the same acceleration a
steps.correctAnswer: Block (down plane positive): m₁g sin(37°) - T = m₁a → 30 - T = 5a. Hanging mass (down positive): m₂g - T = m₂a → 30 - T = 3a
options: Block (down plane positive): m₁g sin(37°) - T = m₁a → 30 - T = 5a. Hanging mass (down positive): m₂g - T = m₂a → 30 - T = 3a
Block: T - m₁g sin(37°) = m₁a. Hanging mass: T - m₂g = m₂a
Both: m₁g sin(37°) + m₂g = (m₁ + m₂)a → 60 = 8a
Block: 30 = 5a. Hanging mass: 30 = 3a (solving separately)
steps.explanation: Critical: Both masses have same acceleration (connected by inextensible string). Direction matters - choose consistent positive direction. Tension opposes motion for both.

steps.stepDescription: Eliminate T and solve for acceleration
steps.correctAnswer: From eq1: T = 30 - 5a. Substitute into eq2: 30 - (30 - 5a) = 3a → 5a = 3a → 2a = 0 → a = 0 m/s². (System is in equilibrium)
options: From eq1: T = 30 - 5a. Substitute into eq2: 30 - (30 - 5a) = 3a → 5a = 3a → 2a = 0 → a = 0 m/s². (System is in equilibrium)
Subtract equations: 0 = 5a - 3a → a = 0 (wrong method). OR a = 3 m/s² (arbitrary)
Add equations: 60 - 2T = 8a. Then use T = 30 to get 0 = 8a, so a = 0
Subtract: 2a = 0, therefore a = 1.5 m/s²
steps.explanation: Subtracting the equations (30 - T = 5a) - (30 - T = 3a) gives 0 = 2a, so a = 0. The system is in equilibrium! This is counterintuitive: the 3kg hanging mass exactly balances the 30N component down the 37° plane.

steps.stepDescription: Interpret the result in context
steps.correctAnswer: The weight of hanging mass (30 N) exactly equals the component of block's weight down the plane (30 N). The system remains at rest (a = 0). Tension T = 30 N throughout.
options: The weight of hanging mass (30 N) exactly equals the component of block's weight down the plane (30 N). The system remains at rest (a = 0). Tension T = 30 N throughout.
The system accelerates down the plane because the hanging mass is pulling it
The block accelerates up the plane at 3 m/s²
Both masses accelerate, but in opposite directions
steps.explanation: This problem teaches that equilibrium is possible in dynamic systems. Students often assume 'system' means motion, but here forces are perfectly balanced. This is a critical conceptual insight.

keyLearningObjectives: Apply Newton's second law to multiple bodies
Recognize constraints (connected by string = same acceleration)
Identify equilibrium conditions in complex systems
commonMisconceptions: Assuming motion must occur in a system (static equilibrium is possible)
Not recognizing both masses have same magnitude of acceleration
Confusing direction conventions leading to wrong signs in equations
Using sin and cos incorrectly for incline problems

problems.subject: Physics
problems.problemStatement: Two objects at different temperatures are placed in thermal contact in an isolated system. Which statement correctly describes what happens?

steps.stepDescription: Recall the definition and conditions for thermal equilibrium
steps.correctAnswer: Thermal equilibrium occurs when two objects reach the same temperature and there is no net heat flow between them.
options: Thermal equilibrium occurs when two objects reach the same temperature and there is no net heat flow between them.
Thermal equilibrium is when both objects have zero temperature
Thermal equilibrium occurs when the hotter object transfers all its heat to the cooler object
Thermal equilibrium requires both objects to have the same mass and specific heat
steps.explanation: Temperature equality is the defining characteristic. Heat flow depends on temperature difference; when equal, net flow = 0.

steps.stepTitle: Identify the direction of heat flow
steps.stepDescription: Apply the second law of thermodynamics
steps.correctAnswer: Heat flows spontaneously from the hotter object to the cooler object until their temperatures become equal.
options: Heat flows spontaneously from the hotter object to the cooler object until their temperatures become equal.
Heat flows from cooler to hotter object (spontaneous cooling of cold object)
Heat can flow in either direction depending on the objects' masses
Heat flows from both objects equally outward
steps.explanation: Second law: heat flows from high T to low T spontaneously. Reverse flow requires work (not spontaneous).

steps.stepDescription: State what happens in an isolated system after sufficient time
steps.correctAnswer: Eventually, both objects reach an intermediate temperature called the final equilibrium temperature, and remain at that temperature with no further net heat exchange.
options: Eventually, both objects reach an intermediate temperature called the final equilibrium temperature, and remain at that temperature with no further net heat exchange.
The hotter object cools to absolute zero while the cooler object heats up
The objects reach room temperature because they are isolated
The temperature difference remains constant forever
steps.explanation: Equilibrium temperature is between initial temperatures. In isolation, both temperature and total internal energy remain constant after equilibrium.

commonMisconceptions: Thinking heat and temperature are identical
Assuming heat can flow from cold to hot spontaneously
Not recognizing that isolated systems reach steady state

problems.subject: Physics
problems.problemStatement: An ambulance with siren frequency 1000 Hz moves toward a stationary observer at 20 m/s. The speed of sound is 340 m/s. Find the frequency heard by the observer.

steps.stepDescription: Determine which form of Doppler equation applies
steps.correctAnswer: Source moving toward stationary observer: f' = f(v_sound)/(v_sound - v_source)
options: Source moving toward stationary observer: f' = f(v_sound)/(v_sound - v_source)
Observer moving toward stationary source: f' = f(1 + v_observer/v_sound)
Both moving toward each other: f' = f(v_sound + v_observer)/(v_sound - v_source)
Source moving away: f' = f(v_sound)/(v_sound + v_source)
steps.explanation: Critical: source approaching stationary observer uses denominator (v - v_source). Observer approaching uses numerator (v + v_obs). Easy to confuse.

steps.stepDescription: Apply the correct Doppler formula with given values
steps.explanation: Source moving toward observer decreases wavelength → higher frequency → denominator is smaller. Option 3 has inverted fraction (observer moving away formula).

steps.stepDescription: Compute the numerical result
steps.explanation: Approaching source: observed frequency > source frequency. 1063 Hz > 1000 Hz confirms answer. Option 2 (941 Hz) would be for receding source.

keyLearningObjectives: Identify correct Doppler formula for scenario
commonMisconceptions: Confusing approaching vs receding scenarios
Using wrong Doppler formula for the given condition
Not recognizing that observed frequency increases for approaching source

problems.subject: Chemistry
problems.problemStatement: Compare and contrast ionic and covalent bonds in terms of electron transfer/sharing and the types of elements involved.

steps.stepTitle: Define electron transfer in ionic bonds
steps.stepDescription: Explain the mechanism of ionic bonding
steps.correctAnswer: Ionic bonds form through complete electron transfer from a metal to a nonmetal, creating charged ions (cation and anion) that attract electrostatically.
options: Ionic bonds form through complete electron transfer from a metal to a nonmetal, creating charged ions (cation and anion) that attract electrostatically.
Ionic bonds form when two nonmetals share electrons equally
Ionic bonds involve overlapping electron orbitals between two atoms
Ionic bonds are formed by the attraction of two positive ions
steps.explanation: Ionic = electron transfer (from metal to nonmetal). This is distinct from sharing. Creates ions with opposite charges.

steps.stepTitle: Define electron sharing in covalent bonds
steps.stepDescription: Explain the mechanism of covalent bonding
steps.correctAnswer: Covalent bonds form when two nonmetals share electron pairs, with electrons occupying orbitals around both nuclei.
options: Covalent bonds form when two nonmetals share electron pairs, with electrons occupying orbitals around both nuclei.
Covalent bonds form when one atom completely transfers electrons to another
Covalent bonds form between a metal and a nonmetal
Covalent bonds involve the complete removal of valence electrons
steps.explanation: Covalent = electron sharing (not transfer). Electrons move between nuclei. Typically nonmetal-nonmetal bonds.

steps.stepDescription: Relate bond type to electronegativity values
steps.correctAnswer: Ionic bonds occur with large electronegativity differences (>1.7) where complete transfer is favorable. Covalent bonds occur with small electronegativity differences (<1.7) where sharing is favorable.
options: Ionic bonds occur with large electronegativity differences (>1.7) where complete transfer is favorable. Covalent bonds occur with small electronegativity differences (<1.7) where sharing is favorable.
Both bond types have the same electronegativity difference
Covalent bonds require larger electronegativity differences than ionic bonds
Electronegativity difference is irrelevant to bond type
steps.explanation: Large EN difference → electron transfer (ionic). Small EN difference → electron sharing (covalent). This is a predictive principle.

keyLearningObjectives: Distinguish electron transfer from electron sharing
Classify bonds based on element type
commonMisconceptions: Confusing ionic and covalent bonding mechanisms
Thinking ionic bonds occur between nonmetals
Not understanding that electronegativity determines bond type

problems.subject: Chemistry
problems.problemStatement: Consider the reaction: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O. If 10 g of H₂ reacts with 50 g of O₂, determine the limiting reactant and calculate the mass of water produced. (Atomic masses: H = 1, O = 16)

steps.stepDescription: Determine molar masses of all reactants
steps.correctAnswer: M(H₂) = 2 g/mol, M(O₂) = 32 g/mol, M(H₂O) = 18 g/mol
options: M(H₂) = 2 g/mol, M(O₂) = 32 g/mol, M(H₂O) = 18 g/mol
M(H₂) = 1 g/mol, M(O₂) = 16 g/mol, M(H₂O) = 18 g/mol
M(H₂) = 2 g/mol, M(O₂) = 16 g/mol, M(H₂O) = 17 g/mol
M(H₂) = 2 g/mol, M(O₂) = 48 g/mol, M(H₂O) = 18 g/mol
steps.explanation: O₂ has two oxygen atoms: 16 + 16 = 32 g/mol. H₂O: 1+1+16 = 18 g/mol. Common error: using atomic masses instead of molar masses.

steps.stepDescription: Calculate moles of each reactant using n = mass/molar mass
options: n(H₂) = 10 mol, n(O₂) = 50 mol
n(H₂) = 2 mol, n(O₂) = 32 mol
n(H₂) = 5 mol, n(O₂) = 1.56 mol × 2 = 3.12 mol (wrong stoichiometry)
steps.explanation: Simple dimensional analysis: divide mass by molar mass. Option 2 forgets to divide. Option 4 incorrectly applies stoichiometric ratio here.

steps.stepDescription: Compare mole ratio to stoichiometric ratio (2:1 for H₂:O₂)
steps.correctAnswer: Stoichiometric ratio H₂:O₂ = 2:1. Available ratio = 5:1.56 = 3.2:1. Since 3.2 > 2, we have excess H₂. O₂ is the limiting reactant.
options: Stoichiometric ratio H₂:O₂ = 2:1. Available ratio = 5:1.56 = 3.2:1. Since 3.2 > 2, we have excess H₂. O₂ is the limiting reactant.
Since 50 g of O₂ > 10 g of H₂, oxygen is in excess. H₂ is limiting.
Since we have 5 mol of H₂ and only 1.56 mol of O₂, H₂ is limiting
Both are consumed completely; neither is limiting.
steps.explanation: Must compare mole ratio to stoichiometric ratio, NOT masses. Option 2 uses mass (wrong). Option 3 compares moles incorrectly (confuses larger quantity with excess).

steps.stepDescription: Use limiting reactant (O₂) to calculate water produced
steps.correctAnswer: From reaction: 1 mol O₂ produces 2 mol H₂O. So 1.56 mol O₂ produces 3.12 mol H₂O. Mass = 3.12 × 18 = 56.16 g ≈ 56.2 g
options: From reaction: 1 mol O₂ produces 2 mol H₂O. So 1.56 mol O₂ produces 3.12 mol H₂O. Mass = 3.12 × 18 = 56.16 g ≈ 56.2 g
From reaction: 2 mol H₂ produces 2 mol H₂O. So 5 mol H₂ produces 5 mol H₂O. Mass = 5 × 18 = 90 g
Total mass of products = 10 + 50 = 60 g (conservation of mass with wrong reactants)
1.56 mol O₂ × 18 g/mol = 28.08 g (directly uses O₂ mass as product)
steps.explanation: Must use stoichiometric ratio from balanced equation (1 O₂ : 2 H₂O). Option 2 uses excess H₂ instead of limiting O₂. Option 3 ignores stoichiometry. Option 4 confuses mass.

commonMisconceptions: Comparing masses instead of moles for limiting reactant
Using larger quantity as 'in excess' without checking ratios
Forgetting stoichiometric coefficients in product calculations
Using excess reactant instead of limiting reactant

problems.subject: Chemistry
problems.problemStatement: A solution has a hydrogen ion concentration [H⁺] = 1 × 10⁻⁴ M. Calculate the pH and pOH of this solution. (Kw = 1 × 10⁻¹⁴ at 25°C)

steps.stepDescription: Use the definition of pH
options: pH = log[H⁺] = log(1 × 10⁻⁴) = -4
steps.explanation: pH uses logarithm: -log(10⁻⁴) = -(-4) = 4. Option 2 forgets the negative sign. Option 3 confuses concentration with pH.

steps.stepDescription: Apply pH + pOH = 14 at 25°C
steps.correctAnswer: pH + pOH = 14, so pOH = 14 - pH = 14 - 4 = 10
options: pH + pOH = 14, so pOH = 14 - pH = 14 - 4 = 10
pOH = pH = 4 (both should be equal)
pOH = pH + Kw = 4 + 1 × 10⁻¹⁴ ≈ 4
pOH = 10⁻⁴ = 0.0001 (pOH is concentration)
steps.explanation: Relationship: pH + pOH = pKw = 14 at 25°C. This is fundamental. Option 2 forgets the sum equals 14.

keyLearningObjectives: Understand pH as logarithmic concentration measure
commonMisconceptions: Confusing concentration with pH
Forgetting that pH + pOH = 14
Not recognizing the logarithmic scale and negative sign

problems.subject: Chemistry
problems.problemStatement: Given: (1) C(s) + O₂(g) → CO₂(g)  ΔH₁ = -393.5 kJ. (2) 2CO(g) + O₂(g) → 2CO₂(g)  ΔH₂ = -566 kJ. Find ΔH for: 2C(s) + O₂(g) → 2CO(g)

steps.stepDescription: Write the reaction whose ΔH is required
steps.correctAnswer: Target: 2C(s) + O₂(g) → 2CO(g)
options: Target: 2C(s) + O₂(g) → 2CO(g)
Target: C(s) + O₂(g) → CO₂(g)
Target: C(s) + ½O₂(g) → CO(g)
Target: 2CO(g) → 2C(s) + O₂(g)
steps.explanation: Clearly restate the target to guide the manipulation of given equations.

steps.stepTitle: Manipulate given equations to form target
steps.stepDescription: Use algebraic operations (multiply, reverse, add) to construct target
steps.correctAnswer: Equation (1) × 2: 2C(s) + 2O₂(g) → 2CO₂(g)  ΔH = 2(-393.5) = -787 kJ. Reverse equation (2): 2CO₂(g) → 2CO(g) + O₂(g)  ΔH = -(-566) = +566 kJ. Add them.
options: Equation (1) × 2: 2C(s) + 2O₂(g) → 2CO₂(g)  ΔH = 2(-393.5) = -787 kJ. Reverse equation (2): 2CO₂(g) → 2CO(g) + O₂(g)  ΔH = -(-566) = +566 kJ. Add them.
Just subtract: ΔH = ΔH₂ - ΔH₁ = -566 - (-393.5) = -172.5 kJ
Use equation (1) directly; equation (2) is irrelevant
Add both equations directly without manipulation: ΔH = -393.5 + (-566) = -959.5 kJ
steps.explanation: Hess's Law: reactions can be added like algebraic equations. Must reverse Eq(2) to eliminate CO₂. Must double Eq(1) to get 2C. Option 2 is random subtraction without Hess manipulation.

steps.stepDescription: Combine equations and calculate net ΔH
steps.correctAnswer: 2C(s) + 2O₂(g) → 2CO₂(g)  ΔH = -787 kJ, PLUS 2CO₂(g) → 2CO(g) + O₂(g)  ΔH = +566 kJ. Net: 2C(s) + O₂(g) → 2CO(g). ΔH = -787 + 566 = -221 kJ
options: 2C(s) + 2O₂(g) → 2CO₂(g)  ΔH = -787 kJ, PLUS 2CO₂(g) → 2CO(g) + O₂(g)  ΔH = +566 kJ. Net: 2C(s) + O₂(g) → 2CO(g). ΔH = -787 + 566 = -221 kJ
ΔH = -787 + 566 = 221 kJ (positive, wrong sign)
ΔH = -787 - 566 = -1353 kJ (should add, not both same sign)
steps.explanation: When adding: one ΔH is negative (exo), one is positive (endo). Net = -221 kJ (overall exothermic). Signs matter in Hess's Law; students often drop negative signs.

keyLearningObjectives: Manipulate chemical equations while tracking ΔH
Understand enthalpy is state function (path independent)
commonMisconceptions: Not reversing equation when direction is reversed
Forgetting to multiply ΔH when scaling equation
Confusion about sign convention for endothermic steps
Random subtraction instead of systematic Hess manipulation

problems.subject: Chemistry
problems.problemStatement: Balance the redox equation in acidic solution: MnO₄⁻(aq) + Fe²⁺(aq) → Mn²⁺(aq) + Fe³⁺(aq)

steps.stepDescription: Determine oxidation state changes for each element
steps.correctAnswer: Mn in MnO₄⁻: +7. Mn in Mn²⁺: +2 (gains 5e⁻, reduction, cathode). Fe in Fe²⁺: +2. Fe in Fe³⁺: +3 (loses 1e⁻, oxidation, anode).
options: Mn in MnO₄⁻: +7. Mn in Mn²⁺: +2 (gains 5e⁻, reduction, cathode). Fe in Fe²⁺: +2. Fe in Fe³⁺: +3 (loses 1e⁻, oxidation, anode).
Mn in MnO₄⁻: +4. Mn in Mn²⁺: +2. Fe unchanged.
All oxidation states are zero; no redox occurs
Mn: +7 → +2 (loses 5e⁻), Fe: +2 → +3 (gains 1e⁻) [wrong directions]
steps.explanation: Mn changes from +7 to +2: reduction (gains electrons). Fe changes from +2 to +3: oxidation (loses). Option 4 reverses the processes.

steps.stepDescription: Separate oxidation and reduction, balance electron transfer
steps.correctAnswer: Reduction: MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O (Mn gains 5e⁻). Oxidation: Fe²⁺ → Fe³⁺ + e⁻ (Fe loses 1e⁻). LCM(5,1)=5, so multiply oxidation by 5: 5Fe²⁺ → 5Fe³⁺ + 5e⁻
options: Reduction: MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O (Mn gains 5e⁻). Oxidation: Fe²⁺ → Fe³⁺ + e⁻ (Fe loses 1e⁻). LCM(5,1)=5, so multiply oxidation by 5: 5Fe²⁺ → 5Fe³⁺ + 5e⁻
Reduction: MnO₄⁻ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ (no water, no H⁺). Oxidation: Fe²⁺ → Fe³⁺ + e⁻
Both half-reactions already balanced; no electron matching needed
Multiply reduction by 1 and oxidation by 5 separately, then add [incomplete electron balance]
steps.explanation: In acidic solution, balance O with H₂O, then H with H⁺. Electrons must be equal before adding. Option 2 omits H₂O and H⁺ (incomplete in acidic medium).

steps.stepDescription: Add half-reactions and cancel species, check atom/charge balance
steps.correctAnswer: MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5Fe²⁺ → Mn²⁺ + 5Fe³⁺ + 4H₂O. Check: Atoms balanced (Mn:1, Fe:5, O:4, H:8). Charge: Left = 1(-1) + 8(+1) + 5(+2) = +17. Right = 1(+2) + 5(+3) = +17 ✓
options: MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5Fe²⁺ → Mn²⁺ + 5Fe³⁺ + 4H₂O. Check: Atoms balanced (Mn:1, Fe:5, O:4, H:8). Charge: Left = 1(-1) + 8(+1) + 5(+2) = +17. Right = 1(+2) + 5(+3) = +17 ✓
MnO₄⁻ + 2H⁺ + Fe²⁺ → Mn²⁺ + Fe³⁺ + H₂O (coefficients too small)
MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5Fe²⁺ → Mn²⁺ + 5Fe³⁺ + 8H₂O (too much water)
No H⁺ or H₂O (treats as if basic or neutral, not acidic)
steps.explanation: Coefficient of 5 comes from LCM of electrons. Coefficient of 4H₂O balances O from MnO₄⁻. Acidic solution requires H⁺ explicitly.

keyLearningObjectives: Balance half-reactions including H⁺ and H₂O
commonMisconceptions: Forgetting H⁺ and H₂O in acidic solution
Not finding LCM of electrons correctly
Mixing up oxidation (loss) and reduction (gain) directions
Not verifying atom and charge balance

problems.subject: Mathematics

steps.stepTitle: Recall the power rule for derivatives
steps.stepDescription: State the general differentiation rule
steps.correctAnswer: Power rule: d/dx(xⁿ) = n·xⁿ⁻¹. Constant rule: d/dx(c) = 0. Sum rule: derivative of sum = sum of derivatives
options: Power rule: d/dx(xⁿ) = n·xⁿ⁻¹. Constant rule: d/dx(c) = 0. Sum rule: derivative of sum = sum of derivatives
d/dx(xⁿ) = xⁿ⁻¹ (missing the coefficient n)
d/dx(xⁿ) = n·xⁿ (power stays the same)
All terms are constants, derivative is 0
steps.explanation: Power rule is fundamental. Option 2 omits the n coefficient. Option 3 adds instead of subtracts exponent. These are common procedural errors.

steps.stepDescription: Apply the power rule to each term separately
steps.correctAnswer: d/dx(5x³) = 5·3x² = 15x². d/dx(-2x²) = -2·2x = -4x. d/dx(3x) = 3. d/dx(-7) = 0. (Recall: 3x = 3x¹, so d/dx(3x) = 3·1·x⁰ = 3)
options: d/dx(5x³) = 5·3x² = 15x². d/dx(-2x²) = -2·2x = -4x. d/dx(3x) = 3. d/dx(-7) = 0. (Recall: 3x = 3x¹, so d/dx(3x) = 3·1·x⁰ = 3)
d/dx(5x³) = 15x². d/dx(-2x²) = -4x. d/dx(3x) = 3x. d/dx(-7) = 0
d/dx(5x³) = 5x². d/dx(-2x²) = -2x. d/dx(3x) = 3. d/dx(-7) = 0
d/dx(5x³) = 15x³. d/dx(-2x²) = -4x². d/dx(3x) = 3x. d/dx(-7) = -7
steps.explanation: Option 2 treats 3x incorrectly (3x → 3x instead of 3x⁰ = 3). Option 3 forgets coefficient in first term (5·3 not just 3). Option 4 keeps exponents same (power rule misapplied).

steps.stepDescription: Write f'(x) as sum of differentiated terms
options: f'(x) = 15x³ - 4x² + 3x
steps.explanation: Constant term -7 derivatives to 0, not included. Option 3 forgets the -7 → 0 step. Option 4 applies power rule incorrectly (uses wrong exponents).

keyLearningObjectives: Understand the power rule for differentiation
commonMisconceptions: Forgetting the coefficient n in power rule
Not reducing exponent (n-1)
Failing to recognize 3x = 3x¹
Forgetting that constant derivatives to zero

problems.subject: Mathematics

steps.stepTitle: Recall the power rule for integration
steps.stepDescription: State the reverse of differentiation rule
steps.correctAnswer: Power rule: ∫xⁿ dx = xⁿ⁺¹/(n+1) + C, where n ≠ -1. Constant rule: ∫c dx = cx + C. Sum rule: ∫[f(x) + g(x)]dx = ∫f(x)dx + ∫g(x)dx
options: Power rule: ∫xⁿ dx = xⁿ⁺¹/(n+1) + C, where n ≠ -1. Constant rule: ∫c dx = cx + C. Sum rule: ∫[f(x) + g(x)]dx = ∫f(x)dx + ∫g(x)dx
∫xⁿ dx = xⁿ + C (no exponent change)
∫xⁿ dx = xⁿ⁻¹/n + C (wrong direction)
No constant of integration C needed for indefinite integrals
steps.explanation: Integration is reverse of differentiation. Exponent increases (n+1). Constant C is mandatory for indefinite integrals. Option 3 is opposite direction (that's differentiation).

steps.stepDescription: Apply power rule to each term with correct coefficients
options: ∫6x² dx = 6x³. ∫(-4x) dx = -4x². ∫1 dx = 1
∫6x² dx = x³. ∫(-4x) dx = -x². ∫1 dx = x
∫6x² dx = 6x²/2 = 3x². ∫(-4x) dx = -4x. ∫1 dx = 1 (treating as differentiation)
steps.explanation: Must divide by (n+1), not forget the coefficient. 6·(1/3) = 2. -4·(1/2) = -2. Option 2 forgets division by (n+1). Option 3 forgets coefficient 6. Option 4 applies differentiation rules instead.

steps.stepTitle: Combine and add constant of integration
steps.stepDescription: Write the final indefinite integral result
steps.correctAnswer: ∫(6x² - 4x + 1)dx = 2x³ - 2x² + x + C
options: ∫(6x² - 4x + 1)dx = 2x³ - 2x² + x + C
∫(6x² - 4x + 1)dx = 2x³ - 2x² + x
∫(6x² - 4x + 1)dx = 6x³ - 4x² + x + C
∫(6x² - 4x + 1)dx = 2x³ - 2x² + 1 + C
steps.explanation: The constant C is essential in indefinite integrals. Option 2 omits C. Option 3 uses wrong coefficients from Step 2 error. Option 4 treats the constant 1 incorrectly.

Remember the constant of integration C

Forgetting the constant C
Confusing integration with differentiation

steps.stepDescription: State the general formula for 2×2 determinants
steps.correctAnswer:
For a 2×2 matrix |a  b|, det(A) = ad - bc

options:

                     |c  d|

det(A) = (a+d) - (b+c) (sum of diagonals)

problems.subject: Mathematics
problems.problemStatement: Prove that sin²θ + cos²θ = 1 using the Pythagorean theorem and the unit circle.

steps.stepDescription: Define a point on the unit circle
steps.correctAnswer: On the unit circle (radius = 1), consider a point P(x, y) at angle θ from the positive x-axis. By definition, x = cos(θ) and y = sin(θ).
options: On the unit circle (radius = 1), consider a point P(x, y) at angle θ from the positive x-axis. By definition, x = cos(θ) and y = sin(θ).
A point on the circle has x = sin(θ) and y = cos(θ) (swapped definitions)
Any circle with equation x² + y² = c², for arbitrary constant c
The point must be at P(1, 1) regardless of angle θ
steps.explanation: Trigonometric definitions on unit circle: cos = x-coordinate, sin = y-coordinate. Option 2 swaps them (common error). Option 3 generalizes unnecessarily (unit circle specifically).

steps.stepTitle: Apply the equation of the unit circle
steps.stepDescription: Write the equation satisfied by all points on a unit circle
steps.correctAnswer: All points on the unit circle satisfy the equation: x² + y² = 1² = 1 (since radius = 1)
options: All points on the unit circle satisfy the equation: x² + y² = 1² = 1 (since radius = 1)
Points satisfy x² - y² = 1 (hyperbola, not circle)
Points satisfy x + y = 1 (linear equation, not circle)
Only specific points satisfy x² + y² = 1
steps.explanation: Circle equation: x² + y² = r². For unit circle, r = 1. Option 2 is hyperbola. Option 3 is line. Option 4 ignores that ALL points on circle satisfy this equation.

steps.stepDescription: Substitute cos(θ) for x and sin(θ) for y
steps.correctAnswer: Substituting x = cos(θ) and y = sin(θ) into x² + y² = 1 gives: cos²(θ) + sin²(θ) = 1, which is the desired identity.
options: Substituting x = cos(θ) and y = sin(θ) into x² + y² = 1 gives: cos²(θ) + sin²(θ) = 1, which is the desired identity.
Substituting gives sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 0 (wrong equality)
Substituting gives cos(θ) + sin(θ) = 1 (linear form, not squared)
The substitution yields (cos·θ)² + (sin·θ)² = 1 (misinterprets notation)
steps.explanation: Direct substitution and algebraic rearrangement. Option 2 has wrong constant. Option 3 loses the squares. Option 4 misinterprets function notation (cos²θ ≠ cos·θ²).

keyLearningObjectives: Understand trigonometric definitions on unit circle
Apply equation of circle in coordinate geometry
commonMisconceptions: Confusing sin and cos definitions
Not recognizing x² + y² = 1 as fundamental to unit circle
Forgetting that proof uses geometric definition, not algebraic manipulation

problems.subject: Mathematics
problems.problemStatement: Solve the quadratic equation 2x² - 5x + 3 = 0 using the quadratic formula.

steps.stepDescription: From the form ax² + bx + c = 0, extract a, b, c
options: a = 2, b = 5, c = 3 (wrong sign for b)
a = 1, b = -5, c = 3 (forgets coefficient of x²)
a = 2, b = -5, c = -3 (wrong sign for c)
steps.explanation: Coefficient includes sign. b = -5 (negative), not +5. a is the x² coefficient, not 1. c = 3 (positive) from +3.

steps.stepDescription: State the formula for solving quadratic equations
steps.correctAnswer: Quadratic formula: x = [-b ± √(b² - 4ac)] / (2a)
options: Quadratic formula: x = [-b ± √(b² - 4ac)] / (2a)
x = [b ± √(b² - 4ac)] / (2a) (missing negative on b)
x = [-b ± √(b² - 4ac)] / a (wrong denominator)
x = [-b ± √(b - 4ac)] / (2a) (missing square on b)
steps.explanation: Formula has: -b (negative b), discriminant = b² - 4ac, denominator = 2a. Option 2 forgets the negative. Option 3 uses a instead of 2a. Option 4 misses the square on b.

steps.stepDescription: Find b² - 4ac, then substitute all values
options: Discriminant: 5² - 4(2)(3) = 25 - 24 = 1. Then x = (5 ± 1) / 4 (treats -b as b)
Discriminant: (-5)² - 4(2)(3) = -25 - 24 = -49 (wrong arithmetic)
steps.explanation: Must compute -(-5) = +5 in numerator. Option 2 forgets -(-5) = +5. Option 3 uses unsigned b. Option 4 miscalculates 25 as -25.

steps.stepDescription: Evaluate both ± solutions
options: x = 5 + 1 = 6, x = 5 - 1 = 4 (forgot to divide by 4)
x = 6/4 = 1.5, x = 4/4 = 1 (only simplifies one root)
x = 1.25, x = 1 (miscalculates 6/4)
steps.explanation: Must divide both numerator parts by denominator 4. 6/4 = 3/2 = 1.5. 4/4 = 1. Option 2 forgets division. Option 4 calculates 6/4 as 1.25 instead of 1.5.

keyLearningObjectives: Handle negative numbers and double negatives
commonMisconceptions: Ignoring signs when identifying coefficients
Forgetting the negative in the numerator of the formula
Computational errors with double negatives
Not simplifying roots completely
